OCRIPLASMIN

  • Pregnancy

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Treatment of vitreomacular traction, including when associated with a macular hole of diameter less than or equal to 400 microns (specialist use only),

By intravitreal injection

  • For adults
    125 micrograms for 1 dose, to be administered into the affected eye, concurrent administration to both eyes is not recommended.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises use only if potential benefit outweighs risk—no information available.

Contra indications

  • Active or suspected ocular or periocular infection
  • aphakia
  • exudative age-related macular degeneration
  • high myopia
  • history of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment
  • ischaemic retinopathies
  • large diameter macular hole (> 400 microns)
  • lens zonule instability
  • proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • recent intra-ocular injection (including laser therapy)
  • recent ocular surgery
  • retinal vein occlusions
  • vitreous haemorrhage

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Abnormal retinograph, anterior chamber cell or flare, chromatopsia, conjunctival disorders, eyelid oedema, iritis, macular degeneration, macular hole, macular oedema, metamorphopsia, ocular discomfort, ocular hyperaemia, photophobia, photopsia, raised intra-ocular pressure, reduced visual acuity, retinal disorders, retinal pigment epitheliopathy, vitreous disorders,

uncommon: Anterior chamber inflammation, corneal abrasion, diplopia, eye inflammation, hyphaema, lens subluxation, miosis, scotoma, transient blindness, unequal pupils, visual field defect,

Directions for administration

For further information on administration, consult product literature.

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA297

Ocriplasmin for treating vitreomacular traction (October 2013)

Ocriplasmin is recommended as an option for treating vitreomacular traction in adults, only if:

  • an epiretinal membrane is not present and
  • they have a stage II full-thickness macular hole with a diameter of 400 microns or less and/or
  • they have severe symptoms.
www.nice.org.uk/TA297 www.nice.org.uk/TA297

Cautions regarding administration

  • History of uveitis (including severe active inflammation)
  • non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy
  • significant eye trauma

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor intra-ocular pressure, visual acuity, and for signs of intra-ocular inflammation or infection following injection.

Prepared medicinal forms of OCRIPLASMIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Solution for injection
